channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hamas Leader Killed in Gaza Fighting, Israel Says
item.description: The Israeli military confirmed that Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, was killed on Wednesday. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he spoke with President Biden about working to advance a deal “to free the hostages.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: What Yahya Sinwar’s Death Could Mean for the Gaza Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The killing of Hamas’s leader may allow Israel to claim victory and agree to a cease-fire, and new Hamas leadership could be more open to compromise. But neither side is likely to immediately change course.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Families and supporters of hostages, some noting the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, demonstrated in favor of a truce in Tel Aviv, on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Prepares Quick, Rescheduled Visit to Germany, a Key Ally
item.description: The president’s hastily rescheduled trip to Berlin will last less than a day. The German government has trimmed back its celebrations accordingly.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden preparing to board Air Force One, en route to Berlin, at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Thursday.

item.title: Meloni’s Balancing Act: Centrist Abroad, Right Wing at Home
item.description: New policies on surrogate births and the treatment of asylum seekers, while largely symbolic, are designed to shore up her right-wing flank in Italy, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Italian prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, at a session in Rome related to an upcoming European Council meeting. She has moved away from her past association with hard-right politics.

item.title: Egypt Replaces Its Powerful Spy Chief, a Key Gaza Mediator
item.description: Gen. Abbas Kamel, a longtime confidant of Egypt’s president, oversaw the country’s most important international relationships and helped maintain the president’s authoritarian grip.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Egyptian Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Egyptian presidency in 2023 of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, center, and Gen. Abbas Kamel, second from right, the head of the country’s intelligence services.

item.title: Gazans So Malnourished That They Could Face Famine, Report Warns
item.description: A hunger emergency has affected nearly all of Gaza, but the situation is worst for people in the north, where Israeli forces intensified operations this month, the report said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Palestinians gathering to receive food aid in Jabaliya, in northern Gaza, in August.

item.title: Alone in the Dark: The Nightmare of Bangladesh’s Secret Underground Prison
item.description: In the House of Mirrors, political captives were pushed to the brink of insanity and death. Some are telling their stories now that the woman who put them there, Sheikh Hasina, is gone.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Shayeza Walid and Atul Loke
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of Sajedul Islam Sumon, a victim of an enforced disappearance, after hearing unverified reports of his death in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in August.

item.title: Zelensky Outlines Ukraine’s ‘Victory Plan’ to EU Leaders
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made an urgent plea in Brussels, though it’s unclear to what extent the officials gathered there will go along with it.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told the gathering in Brussels that Russia would “resort to diplomacy” only “when it sees that it cannot achieve anything by force.”

item.title: Indian Doctors Go on Hunger Strike to Protest Killing of Colleague
item.description: Six were subsisting only on water and were admitted into the hospital after a multiday fast to demand justice for the brutal rape and killing of a medical resident.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Medical workers on a hunger strike in Kolkata, India, last week to protest the rape and killing of a colleague.

item.title: Moscow Roils a Country on the Edge of Europe and Russia
item.description: Russia is behind a disinformation campaign in Moldova ahead of a presidential election and a referendum making E.U. membership a “strategic objective,” Moldovan officials and global media companies say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supporter of Moldova’s joining the European Union handed out leaflets last week in Chisinau, Moldova, urging people to vote in a referendum.

item.title: Peru Pañamarca Archaeological Site Finds ‘Hall of the Braided Serpents’
item.description: Archaeologists have unearthed a richly decorated throne room and a “Hall of the Braided Serpents” from the Moche culture, with clues that a woman may have ruled there more than 1,300 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: A figure painted on a pillar at Pañamarca, Peru, where archaeologists have uncovered evidence of a female ruler.

item.title: Former Seoul Police Chief Acquitted in Halloween Crowd Crush Case
item.description: Kim Kwang-ho, the former head of the Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency, was the most senior official to face criminal charges over the 2022 disaster that killed 159 people.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers guarding the site of the crowd crush in Seoul a few days after the disaster in 2022.

item.title: Mexico’s Ex-Security Chief Sentenced to 38 Years for Cartel Bribery
item.description: The stiff penalty was the potentially final step in the stunning downfall of the former official, Genaro García Luna, who has gone from the heights of power to imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Genaro García Luna in 2012, during his tenure as Mexico’s public security minister.

item.title: Italy Passes Law Banning People From Seeking Surrogacy Abroad
item.description: The new law was pushed by the party of Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s conservative prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A protest organized by families and L.G.B.T.Q. associations to support surrogacy in Rome in April.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The leader of Hamas is dead.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the Palestinian leader of Hamas in the Gaza Strip, at a rally in 2021.

item.title: Ukraine Draft Officers Detain Men After Concert Amid Ongoing Russia War
item.description: Men who attended the Kyiv concert of a popular rock band had their papers checked on the way out. Some were detained. Tickets to subsequent shows suddenly became available.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Draft officers and the police waited outside a Kyiv concert hall after a sold-out show by Okean Elzy, looking for men trying to dodge military service.

item.title: Hamas Leader Yahya Sinwar Was Killed After a Surprise Battlefield Encounter
item.description: Although Yahya Sinwar was a major target of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, the soldiers who killed the militant chief had not expected to run across him, Israeli officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Raja Abdulrahim, Patrick Kingsley and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar in Gaza City before the war.

item.title: Israeli Military Drone Footage Claims to Show Yahya Sinwar Shortly Before He Was Killed
item.description: The video shows a room that matches photographs obtained by The Times that show the corpse of a man closely resembling the Hamas leader.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: David Lammy, U.K. Foreign Secretary, Visits China in Bid to Reset Relations
item.description: David Lammy is set to meet China’s foreign minister in Beijing on Friday, in a trip the British government said would acknowledge “areas of contention as well as areas for cooperation.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: David Lammy speaking at the Labour Party conference last month. “Engagement with China is pragmatic and necessary to support U.K. and global interests,” he said in a statement released ahead of his visit to Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Biden Talks to Netanyahu About Sinwar’s Death and Getting to a Cease-Fire
item.description: After arriving in Berlin for previously scheduled meetings, the president said he was sending the secretary of state to Israel in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: President Biden at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Thursday before leaving for Germany.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The Leader of Hamas is Dead
item.description: Plus, an interview with Hugh Grant.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar in Gaza City last year.

item.title: Behind Nigeria’s Fuel Tanker Explosion, a Fatal Quest for Cheap Gasoline
item.description: More than 160 people died when an overturned fuel tanker in northern Nigeria exploded. Witnesses and relatives of victims said poverty had driven most to try to collect the spilled gas.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Auwal and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Victims of a tanker explosion receive treatment inside an ambulance at the Aminu Kano teaching hospital in Kano, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: How Israeli Military Trainees Found and Killed Hamas Leader Yahya Sinwar in Gaza
item.description: A unit from the Israeli military encountered Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, while on an operation in southern Gaza, Israeli defense officials said.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle driving along the border of Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: In Northern Gaza, Hunger Looms Over Daily Existence
item.description: Families say they are rationing what little food they can find while living under the constant threat of Israeli bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Abu Bakr Bashir and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinians receiving vegetable patties prepared by volunteers in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, in August.

item.title: More Forests Are on Fire, a Big Risk in Climate Change Fight
item.description: Carbon emissions from forest fires increased more than 60 percent globally over the past two decades, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kayle Neis/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A forest fire burning northeast of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, in 2021.

item.title: Yahya Sinwar, Leader of Hamas, Is Dead
item.description: Mr. Sinwar climbed the ranks of the Palestinian militant group to plot the deadliest attack on Israel in its history.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, greeting the audience at the International Quds Day festival in Gaza City in 2023.

item.title: A Look at Hamas’s Leadership Following Sinwar’s Death
item.description: The militant group has long been targeted by Israel.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar in Gaza City last year.

item.title: The U.K. Will Debate Legalizing Assisted Dying. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: A bill introduced in the House of Commons could legalize assisted dying for the terminally ill, under strict conditions. A similar proposal was rejected in 2015.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Wiktor Szymanowicz/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators rally in support of assisted dying in April outside the Houses of Parliament in London.

item.title: U.S. Wrestles With Aiding Allies and Maintaining Its Own Weapons Supply
item.description: Pentagon officials discuss whether the flow of assistance could be hurting the military’s ability to respond to a new conflict.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A THAAD antiballistic missile system in Guam last year. The United States has announced plans to send a similar system to Israel.

item.title: Fan Bingbing, Once China’s Top Actress, Returns to Film Years After Tax Scandal
item.description: Fan was a megastar until 2018, when she was fined tens of millions of dollars over unpaid taxes and her career tanked. “Green Night” is her first film since the scandal.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Yan Cong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fan Bingbing in Beijing in 2019. The year before, she was at the peak of her career.

item.title: He Didn’t See Daylight for Five Years
item.description: Here are some basics from the Times investigation into Bangladesh’s secret military prison, the “House of Mirrors.”
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Shayeza Walid
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times.
item.media:description: Relatives of victims of enforced disappearances comforting one another while protesting in August in Bangladesh’s capital, Dhaka.

item.title: U.S. Bombs Weapons Caches of Iran-Backed Houthis in Yemen
item.description: Air Force B-2 bombers struck five underground weapons facilities in what may be a signal from the Biden administration to Iran.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Houthi soldiers in Yemen last month. The U.S. attack was aimed at disrupting the Houthis’ capability to attack ships and disrupt commerce in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, the defense secretary said.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A heated interview with Fox News.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally in Philadelphia on Wednesday.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Urges Israel to Increase Flow of Aid Into Gaza
item.description: Some of the sharpest criticism about a lack of sufficient assistance in the enclave came from Israel’s allies, including the United States.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Riyad Mansour, Palestinian envoy to the United Nations, left, at a Security Council meeting at the United Nations on Wednesday.

item.title: Water Crises Threaten the World’s Food Supply, Studies Show
item.description: Food production is concentrated in too few countries, many of which face water shortages, the researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Watering newly planted corn during a drought in Jinan, China, in June.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Trump Threatens ‘the Enemy From Within’
item.description: Plus, the women of the world’s gnarliest mountain-bike competition.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump at a campaign event in Philadelphia on Monday.

item.title: Trudeau Accuses Political Foes of Engaging in Foreign Interference
item.description: Facing a revolt in his own party, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attacked both the Conservative opposition and India’s government, which he said had made “a horrific mistake” in the killing of a Sikh activist.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaking on Wednesday during a hearing in Ottawa focused on foreign interference into internal Canadian affairs.

item.title: Israeli Strike Hits Lebanese Municipal Building, Killing Mayor
item.description: The strike, in the south of Lebanon, killed at least 16 people, Lebanese officials said. Israel, which also struck near Beirut, said it was targeting Hezbollah militants.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: The Dahiya, an area outside Beirut, after an Israeli airstrike on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Announces $425 Million in Aid to Ukraine
item.description: President Biden spoke by telephone to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine about the security package, which includes munitions, armored vehicles and other weapons.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians leaving an area after Russian bombardment in Kharkiv, Ukraine, in August.

item.title: A Top Chess Player Is Disqualified After a Phone Is Found in a Bathroom Stall
item.description: Kirill Shevchenko, a grandmaster who represents Romania, has been accused of getting assistance from a computer in the middle of games.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Kirill Shevchenko at a tournament in Warsaw earlier this year.

item.title: Plastics Are Turning Up in Dolphin Breath
item.description: Researchers studying bottlenose dolphins found polyester and other plastics in every animal they tested.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dolphins have become a common subject in pollution research because they’re found around the world, including in heavily-populated coastal areas.

item.title: Criminal Network Cashed In on Fake French Wine, the Europol Said
item.description: A criminal network was accused of selling bottles of fake French wine for as much as 15,000 euros. It’s the latest in a growing criminal trend: wine fraud.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: French grapes, like those found at the famous Château Angélus in the Bordeaux region of France, were not used for the wine in the fraudulent bottles of wine said to have been sold by a criminal network.

item.title: Thomas J. Donohue Dies at 86; Transformed Chamber of Commerce
item.description: Under his 24-year leadership, the lobbying group developed enormous clout in Washington, but he broke with the Trump administration over immigration, tariffs and the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas J. Donohue in his office in Washington in 2013. He was a scrappy can-do cheerleader for both corporate America and Main Street.

item.title: In ‘Vladimir,’ a Russian Reporter’s Fight Is an Apt Election Season Tale
item.description: The writer Erika Sheffer takes a big swing in a Manhattan Theater Club production examining “the point at which a society finds itself on the brink.”
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: Norbert Leo Butz and Faridany as two Russian journalists.

item.title: Appointment of Thomas Tuchel, a German, Is Met With Pushback From England Soccer Fans
item.description: The appointment of Thomas Tuchel to coach the England men’s national soccer team has provoked, well, some strong feelings.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: The new coach of the England men’s national soccer team, Thomas Tuchel, center, is a familiar face to Premier League fans.

item.title: 2 Missing After Navy Fighter Jet Crashes Near Mount Rainier
item.description: The two crew members who were onboard the aircraft remain missing, Navy officials said, after it crashed during a routine training flight.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Boeing EA-18G Growler flying over the Aegean Sea in 2022.

item.title: Fuel Tanker Explosion Leaves at Least 150 Dead in Nigeria
item.description: Residents of a nearby town went to scoop up gasoline that had spilled from an overturned tanker, but then it exploded, setting off an inferno. Several similar disasters have taken place in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Auwal and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Carrying a body for a funeral after a fuel tanker explosion in Majia, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Allows Some Aid Into Gaza After U.S. Threatens to Withhold Military Aid
item.description: There was no official response from the Israeli government, a day after the United States threatened consequences if it didn’t let more relief into Gaza within 30 days.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Distributing meals at a charity kitchen in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, in September.

item.title: Zelensky Pitches ‘Victory Plan’ in Ukraine’s Parliament
item.description: The proposal would rely heavily on increased Western assistance. So far, it has drawn a lukewarm response from Ukraine’s allies.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky told Ukraine’s Parliament that his plan had the potential to end the war “no later than next year.”

item.title: For North Korea, War in Ukraine Is a Coveted Chance for Military Practice
item.description: Helping Russia in the war is an opportunity for North Korea to test its new weapons, and Ukrainian officials say the North’s troops are also gaining direct battle experience.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un of North Korea with Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in June, in a broadcast shown in Seoul. During their meeting, Mr. Kim vowed his country’s “full support and solidarity” for Russia in its war in Ukraine.

item.title: Flying Into Storms Improves Forecasts, but It Is Rare in Asia’s Typhoon Alley
item.description: While observational flights have improved forecasts for many storms in the Americas, such flights have been far fewer for storms that have hit Asia.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: With Jets and Ships, China is Honing Its Ability to Choke Taiwan
item.description: China’s large-scale military exercises are encircling Taiwan and testing the island’s defenses. They also raise the risk of conflict, accidental or otherwise.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Scores of Chinese aircraft and dozens of ships surrounded Taiwan, after President Lai Ching-te rejected Beijing’s claim over the island.

item.title: Fleeing Israeli Bombs, the Displaced in Lebanon Search for Safety
item.description: Schools, clubs and parks have become places of refuge as the displaced seek safety amid Israeli bombings.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and David Guttenfelder
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Luís Roberto Barroso, Brazil’s Chief Justice, Defends Supreme Court’s Expanded Power
item.description: The chief justice of Brazil’s Supreme Court, Luís Roberto Barroso, defended the court in the face of growing debate over its aggressive role in politics.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: The chief justice of Brazil’s Supreme Court, Luís Roberto Barroso, defends the court’s investigation into attacks on the court and other government institutions.

item.title: A Beloved Maple Tree Had to Come Down, But It Lives On
item.description: A beloved sugar maple slowly succumbed to disease. Today, it lives on in a new form.
item.dc:creator: Daryln Brewer Hoffstot and Kristian Thacker
item.media:description: Corey Snyder, a wood turner in Pennsylvania, cut sections of a felled sugar maple.

item.title: Is Brazil’s Supreme Court Saving Democracy or Threatening It?
item.description: Brazil’s top court expanded its power to protect democracy. But some are wondering whether the court now represents the threat.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Brazilian Supreme Court building lit in the country’s national colors in Brasília, the capital, last month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A warning from the U.S. to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Trucks carrying aid lined up on the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing with the Gaza Strip last month.

item.title: Global Electricity Demand Is Rising Faster Than Expected, I.E.A. Says
item.description: A surge in power use worldwide could make it harder for nations to slash emissions and keep global warming in check.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: Cooling towers of the shuttered Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near Middletown, Pa., which will reopen in 2028 to supply power to Microsoft data centers.

item.title: Trump’s Changing Views on Talking to Foreign Leaders
item.description: The former president, who once pushed to prosecute a former secretary of state for talking with foreign officials, said that it would be “a good thing” for himself to have secretly kept in touch with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia — if he did.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Jim Vondruska for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s comments on Tuesday once again put his relationship with Russia’s leader at issue, with three weeks left in his campaign to reclaim the White House.

item.title: Israeli Court Orders Government to Explain System for Medical Evacuations From Gaza
item.description: Three Israeli human rights groups in early June, following the closure of the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Johnatan Reiss
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: At least 19 Palestinian children were taken out of Gaza through the Karam Shalom crossing for medical treatment abroad in June.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. Warns it May Cut Israel’s Military Aid
item.description: Plus, an investigation into China’s panda breeding program.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Humanitarian aid trucks waiting to cross the Rafah border crossing between Egypt and Gaza last month.
